Award.AwardTitle: SHF:Small: Collaborative Research: CONTINUOUS-TIME DIGITAL COMPUTATION AND SIGNAL PROCESSING

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research is to develop high-performance and power-efficient digital signal processors, using a novel event-driven approach involving special techniques that carefully keep track of the timing of events. Unlike standard "asynchronous" logic this approach inherently uses physical time as part of its representation of information. The systems and techniques to be developed in course of this research can benefit a number of important applications, including sensor networks and biomedical instrumentation in health care. The body of knowledge to be created would potentially find applications in other areas as well, including control systems and robotics. The work has a significant educational component, in that it involves synergistic development, combining different domains of knowledge and thus training the graduate and undergraduate students involved in interdisciplinary work, leading to new, creative solutions.

Appealing technical properties of this approach include the absence of aliasing, better spectral properties of error, and faster response to changing inputs, compared to classical techniques. The approach is suitable for certain applications that demand very low power dissipation, notably those involving portability or difficult-to-access locations. While prior work concentrated on demonstrating the feasibility of continuous-time digital signal processors, this new effort concentrates on developing next-generation systems and achieving very high performance, necessitating new principles and techniques. The work seeks to advance the performance of continuous-time digital signal processors by reducing the effective sampling rate and improving output reconstruction, by using special coding techniques for relaxing granularity requirements in the signal processing units, by processing directly non-uniformly quantized signals, and by employing algorithmic techniques; it also expands continuous-time digital techniques to general scientific computation. The proposed effort brings together two groups with complementary expertise. The Columbia University group specializes in mixed-signal circuits and has demonstrated the first continuous-time digital signal processors; the Cornell University group works in asynchronous digital electronics, including event-driven processors and asynchronous dataflow FPGAs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our world is full of devices that generate large volumes of data. The data generated by an individual sensor can be viewed mathematically as a function of time (a signal). Converting signals into useful information often involves complex tasks known as digital signal processing, that can demand large energy consumption.

The goal of this research was to develop high-performance event-driven digital signal processors, using special techniques that carefully keep track of the timing of events, unlike conventional asynchronous logic. All circuits involved are designed using clockless circuits that operate in continuous time. The net result is that the entire processing chain—from data conversion to the signal processing algorithms—has dynamic power consumption that depends strongly on the activity of the input signal. This makes the approach suitable for certain important applications that demand very low power dissipation, notably those involving portability or difficult-to-access locations. Such applications include sensor networks and wearable/implantable/ingestible biomedical instrumentation. The work has resulted in both theoretical results and new silicon chips which were used to verify our approach. The proposed effort brought together two groups with complementary expertise. The Columbia group specializes in mixed-signal circuits and has demonstrated the first continuous-time digital signal processors; the Cornell group works in asynchronous digital electronics, including event-driven processors and asynchronous dataflow FPGAs. Together, the two sets of expertise provided a solid foundation on which our results have been based.

Intellectual Merit: The proposed work researched new principles and techniques that make possible fully event-driven systems in which the time between events is an integral part of the signal representation. The research involved the combination of binary logic and continuous-time operation. This is an unusual combination that possesses new properties, distinct from those of conventional systems, leading to a new body of knowledge not encompassed by existing knowledge. The work has been extensively published and enhances the understanding of signal processing, computation and hardware design. 

Broader Impact: The systems and techniques developed in the course of this research can benefit a significant number of important applications, including sensor networks and biomedical instrumentation in health care. The body of knowledge created as part of this project can find application in other areas as well, including control systems and robotics. The work has had a significant educational component, in that it has involved synergistic development, combining different domains of knowledge and thus training the graduate and undergraduate students involved in interdisciplinary work, leading to new, creative solutions.

 

Key Words: Continuous time signal processing; digital signal processing; asynchronous computing; mixed-signal systems; event-driven signal processing.
